sections.title: The Parable of the Wicked Tenants

verses.text: One day, as Jesus was teaching the people in the temple and announcing the good news, the chief priests and scribes with the elders came up to him.
verses.comment: This verse sets the scene for Jesus' confrontation with the religious leaders in the temple, a recurring event showing the tension between Jesus and the temple authorities.

verses.text: They spoke, saying to him, 'Tell us: by what authority do you do these things? Or who is it that gave you this authority?'
verses.comment: 'Authority' (Greek: exousia) is a key term here, relating to Jesus' divine mission and His identity as Son of God. The leaders challenge the source of His authority.

verses.text: He answered them, 'I also will ask you a question. Tell me:
verses.comment: Jesus responds with a counter-question, a rabbinic method to reveal His challengers' motives.

verses.text: Was the baptism of John from heaven or from men?'
verses.comment: 'From heaven' denotes divine origin. Reference to John the Baptist connects Jesus’ ministry to prophetic fulfillment.

verses.text: They debated among themselves, saying, 'If we say,
But if we say, "From men," all the people will stone us, for they are convinced that John was a prophet.'
verses.comment: This illustrates the leaders’ fear of the people and their recognition of John’s prophetic authority.

verses.text: So they answered that they did not know where it was from.
verses.comment: Their refusal to answer reveals their unwillingness to acknowledge God’s work outside their own authority.

verses.text: And Jesus said to them, 'Neither will I tell you by what authority I do these things.'
verses.comment: Because the leaders are insincere, Jesus does not reveal more to them, echoing the theme of faith preceding understanding (Isaiah 29:13-14).

verses.text: Then he began to tell the people this parable: 'A man planted a vineyard, rented it out to tenants, and went on a journey for a long time.'
verses.comment: The vineyard is a common Old Testament image for Israel (Isaiah 5:1-7).
verses.sectionHeader: The Parable of the Wicked Tenants

verses.text: At harvest time, he sent a servant to the tenants to collect some of the fruit from the vineyard. But the tenants beat him and sent him away empty-handed.
verses.comment: The servants symbolize the prophets sent to Israel, who were often rejected or killed.

verses.text: He sent another servant, but they beat that one also, treated him shamefully, and sent him away empty-handed.
verses.comment: This shows the repeated rejection of God’s messengers by His people.

verses.text: He sent a third; this one they wounded and threw out.
verses.comment: The escalation climaxes the hard-heartedness of Israel’s leaders.

verses.text: Then the owner of the vineyard said, 'What shall I do? I will send my beloved son. Perhaps they will respect him.'
verses.comment: The 'beloved son' is a clear Christological reference to Jesus as Son of God. Parallels to the binding of Isaac (Genesis 22) enhance the typology.

verses.text: But when the tenants saw him, they talked it over among themselves and said, 'This is the heir. Let’s kill him, so the inheritance will be ours.'
verses.comment: References to plotting against 'the heir' recall prophetic images of the Messiah's rejection by His own people.

verses.text: So they threw him out of the vineyard and killed him. What then will the owner of the vineyard do to them?
verses.comment: Jesus is cast out and killed 'outside'—a sign of His crucifixion and rejection by the leaders.

verses.text: 'He will come and destroy those tenants and give the vineyard to others.' When they heard this, they said, 'May it never be!'
verses.comment: Jesus prophesies the transfer of God’s people to a new community built around Him and the apostles. The audience’s shock shows the seriousness of the message.

verses.text: But Jesus looked directly at them and said, 'Then what is this that is written: “The stone the builders rejected has become the cornerstone”?'
verses.comment: Jesus applies messianic prophecy to Himself; He is the rejected stone who becomes the foundation of God’s true people.

verses.text: Everyone who falls on that stone will be broken to pieces; but if it falls on anyone, it will crush him.'
verses.comment: The stone, an image for Christ, is both a foundation and a threat to all who reject Him. Fulfillment of the Daniel prophecy about the stone that fills the earth.

verses.text: The scribes and the chief priests tried to lay hands on him that very hour, but feared the people, for they knew he had spoken this parable against them.
verses.comment: The religious leaders’ response shows their hardened hearts, but public opinion restrains their open violence.

verses.text: So they watched him closely and sent spies who pretended to be sincere, so they might catch him in something he said, to deliver him over to the authority and power of the governor.
verses.comment: Their deceit contrasts with Jesus' openness. Reference to the 'governor' points to looming Roman involvement in Jesus' passion.

verses.text: So they asked him, 'Teacher, we know that you speak and teach rightly, and show no partiality, but truly teach the way of God.
verses.comment: Their words are insincere flattery, meant to trap Jesus into a compromising statement.

verses.text: Is it lawful for us to give tribute to Caesar or not?'
verses.comment: This question is a political and religious trap, as taxes to Rome were controversial among the Jews.

verses.text: But he perceived their craftiness and said to them,
verses.comment: Jesus’ divine wisdom discerns their true intentions, echoing God’s knowledge of hearts.

verses.text: 'Show me a denarius. Whose image and inscription does it have?' They said, 'Caesar’s.'
verses.comment: The Roman coin bearing Caesar’s image anchors the discussion in practical reality while hinting at deeper spiritual meaning.

verses.text: He said to them, 'Then give to Caesar the things that are Caesar’s, and to God the things that are God’s.'
verses.comment: Jesus highlights the distinction between civil and divine authority. All things ultimately belong to God, but legitimate civil obligations are acknowledged.

verses.text: And they were not able to catch him in what he said before the people, but marveling at his answer, they became silent.
verses.comment: Jesus’ wisdom silences his opponents, reminiscent of Old Testament accounts where God overcomes the schemes of the wicked.

verses.text: Now some of the Sadducees, who say there is no resurrection, came to him.
verses.comment: The Sadducees were a priestly group who denied bodily resurrection and much of the supernatural. Their question is intended to discredit belief in the resurrection.

verses.text: 'Teacher, Moses wrote for us that if a man’s brother dies, having a wife but no children, the man must marry the widow and raise up offspring for his brother.'
verses.comment: The law of levirate marriage (Deuteronomy 25:5-10) guaranteed family lines in Israel.

verses.text: Now there were seven brothers. The first took a wife and died childless.
verses.comment: This is the beginning of a test case meant to undermine the idea of bodily resurrection.

verses.text: The second and the third married her,
verses.comment: The narrative follows the law’s requirements in an exaggerated way.

verses.text: and in the same way, all seven died, leaving no children. At last, the woman also died.
verses.comment: The Sadducees’ scenario anticipates a dilemma in the resurrection.

verses.text: In the resurrection, therefore, whose wife will she be? For all seven had her as wife.'
verses.comment: Their question tries to show resurrection hope as absurd by appealing to earthly marriage customs.

verses.text: And Jesus said to them, 'The sons of this age marry and are given in marriage,
verses.comment: Marriage is a reality of this earthly age, not the age to come.

verses.text: but those who are considered worthy to attain to that age and to the resurrection from the dead neither marry nor are given in marriage.
verses.comment: Jesus describes a transformed existence after resurrection, where earthly institutions give way to spiritual realities; worthiness here hints at cooperation with grace.

verses.text: For they cannot die anymore, because they are like the angels and are sons of God, being sons of the resurrection.
verses.comment: Resurrected life entails immortality and a new filial relationship with God.

verses.text: But that the dead are raised, even Moses showed at the bush, where he calls the Lord 'the God of Abraham and the God of Isaac and the God of Jacob.'
verses.comment: Jesus argues for the resurrection by appealing to the Pentateuch, authoritative for the Sadducees. God calls Himself the God of the living, not the dead.

verses.text: Now he is not God of the dead, but of the living, for all live to him.'
verses.comment: God’s covenant endures; the patriarchs are alive to Him, supporting the doctrine of the resurrection and the communion of saints.

verses.text: Some of the scribes answered, 'Teacher, you have spoken well.'
verses.comment: Even some opponents acknowledge Jesus’ wisdom, showing the redemptive power of truth, even among those with differing beliefs.

verses.text: For they no longer dared to ask him any question.
verses.comment: After this, Jesus’ authority and wisdom are so evident that no one attempts to challenge Him further.

verses.text: And after that, they did not dare to question him any further.
verses.comment: This verse emphasizes the finality of Jesus’ superiority over His opponents, revealing His authority not only as a teacher, but as the divine Son, and alludes to the foundation of order and authority in the Church.

verses.text: Then he said to them, "How can they say that the Messiah is David's Son?
verses.comment: Jesus challenges the religious leaders with a question about the true identity of the Messiah. This highlights the deeper mystery of Christ: though descended from David by birth, He is greater than David.

verses.text: For David himself says in the Book of Psalms: 'The Lord said to my Lord, "Sit at my right hand,
verses.comment: Quoting Psalm 110:1, Jesus reveals that David recognized the Messiah as his Lord. This is a direct reference to the Messiah's divinity, alluding to Jesus’ unique status—not merely David’s descendant, but Lord over all.

verses.text: until I make your enemies a footstool for your feet.'
verses.comment: Jesus shows that the Messiah holds authority and triumphs over all enemies, emphasizing fulfilled prophecy and Christ’s reign. Early Christians understood this as referring to Jesus' ongoing spiritual kingship.

verses.text: David calls him 'Lord.' So how is he his Son?
verses.comment: Jesus’ question exposes the limits of a purely human view of the Messiah, indicating both his humanity and divinity—a foundational truth for Christian doctrine. This mystery foreshadows Christ’s two natures.

verses.text: While all the people were listening, he said to his disciples,
verses.comment: Jesus turns to his disciples in the presence of the crowd, shifting the focus from debate with the leaders to an exhortation about authentic leadership.

verses.text: "Beware of the scribes, who like to walk around in long robes, love greetings in the marketplaces, the best seats in the synagogues, and the places of honor at banquets.
verses.comment: Jesus warns against religious leaders whose actions are motivated by pride, status, and outward appearance rather than humble service. True spiritual leadership, as modeled by Christ and His apostles, is marked by humility and self-sacrifice.

verses.text: "They devour widows’ houses and for appearance make long prayers. They will receive greater condemnation."
verses.comment: Jesus accuses the scribes of exploiting the vulnerable while pretending to be pious. God demands true justice and mercy, especially towards the poor. This warning underscores the importance of authentic faith—one that cares for the lowly and does not use religion for personal gain. The principle of divine judgment for spiritual leaders is highlighted here, preparing the ground for later Christian emphasis on integrity and sacrificial service.
